key_facts: LinkedIn Series B pitch presented three business ideas with no revenue at the time
The three business ideas were not the source of LinkedIn's majority revenue
Individual subscription was initially believed to be the primary revenue model
Corporate product inquiries began two weeks after launching the individual subscription model
A paper mock-up of the corporate product was created despite not being actively developed
A salesperson was hired to test interest in the corporate product
Twenty out of thirty company contacts expressed interest in purchasing the corporate product
The company pivoted to build the corporate product as its main revenue driver
The corporate product became the majority source of LinkedIn's revenue
The pivot occurred earlier than expected, shifting from a five-year timeline to immediate action
key_opinions: Presenting three options during the pitch reflects uncertainty about the correct path
The shift to corporate product was a strategic necessity driven by market demand
The initial belief in individual subscriptions was incorrect based on actual user behavior
The speed of corporate interest surprised the team and validated the pivot
The corporate product was more viable than anticipated due to strong buyer interest
key_datapoints: 2/3 of the way through LinkedIn Series B pitch, three business ideas were presented
Two weeks after launching individual subscription, corporate inquiries began
Salesperson spoke to 30 people, 20+ showed interest in buying the corporate product
Pivot occurred immediately after receiving positive feedback from potential buyers
Corporate product became the majority revenue source even today
